awd_titl_txt: Southeast Control Conference 2021: A Networking and Brainstorming Opportunity for the Regional DCSD Community; Blacksburg, Virginia; November 29-30, 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the Southeast Control Conference (SECC), which is at its second edition, is to provide an intellectually stimulating environment where student and researchers in the areas of dynamics, control, sensing, and diagnostics can present their research to one another, exchange some of the latest cutting edge research ideas, and build their professional networks. The SECC will be open to participants working in the southeast of the continental US to strengthen a regional network and incentivize rapid exchange of research novelties. Special emphasis will be given to the active recruiting of participants from traditionally underrepresented minorities in engineering and historically black colleges and Universities (HBCUs). The Southeast is home to a number of productive research groups in dynamics, control, and systems theory and, although most of these groups are geographically close to one another, they rarely interact outside a few international conferences, and the depth of interactions at these international conferences is limited due to a large number of attendees and to competing obligations. Most of the topics addressed at SECC fall within the purview of NSF's Dynamics, Control and Systems Diagnostics program, and, by supporting this conference for the first time, NSF will help this innovative new conference to become better established in its first few years of existence by relieving some of the fundraising burdens and enabling the organizers to focus on building sustained awareness and interest in the event, demonstrating the value of the event, and establishing easily replicated procedures for organizing future edition of the SECC.

The SECC 2021 will be structured over one and a half days and will alternate oral presentation sessions and poster presentations with multiple breaks, offering tours of the Virginia Tech campus, and a social banquet. This organization will maximize the attendees’ opportunities to exchange research ideas and network. A guest speaker, possibly a program manager in a relevant federal funding agency, and possibly with a diverse background, will present about their research portfolio and will serve as a potential role model for younger attendees. Speakers will be selected based on the relevance, depth, and breadth of a one-page abstract evaluated by the Program Chairs. As part of the abstract submission process, the candidate speakers’ demographics will be recorded to maximize the opportunities of speakers from diverse research groups and institutions to intervene. A post-conference survey sent to all attendees will allow the Conference organizers to assess the effectiveness of SECC in reaching its goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Supported by NSF through the Dynamics, Control and Systems Diagnostics (DCSD) program, the SouthEast Control Conference (SECC2021) provided an intellectually stimulating environment where latest research results in the areas of dynamics, control, sensing, and diagnostics were presented. Organized over one and half days in the month of November 2021 at the Virginia Tech main campus, this conferece hosted representatives from 11 universities and more than 100 registered attendants, which included  professors, researchers, graduate and undergraduate students, and industry members. 

Thirtynine technical works were presented by graduate students and post-doctoral fellows from multiple departments including aerospace, civil, electrical, industrial, and mechanical engineering, and mathemcaitcs. These works spanned multiple sub-disciplines emcompassed by the DCSD program and their applications were not limited to engineering problems only but spanned other areas, including construction sciences, chemistry, and biology to name some. A large majority of these works were funded by major federal agencies, including NSF, and were presented shortly after at prestigious international conferences such as the Conference on Decision and Control (CDC) and the American Control Conference (ACC) to name but two of the most popular ones. A keynote speaker, Dr. C. Beck, addressed the audience with her most recent results on network systems theory and its applications to infectious diseases transmission and prevention.

The organization of SECC2021 focussed not only on the technical aspects of this work, which played a pivotal role, but also on the networking among participants at coffee breaks, over campus tours, and a social dinner. The outcomes of these networking events have been the establishment and the strengthening of professional relations, the recruitment of talented students, including those from traditionally underrepresented minorities in engineering, and the exposure of practitioners, students, and researchers at all levels to state-of-the-art leading edge research.

 The abstracts of the selected works as well as the conference program and other logistics details were published at the website https://secc21.com. An advisory board comprising faculty from Virginia Tech, Georgia Tech, the University of Florida, and North Carolina A&T contributed to the organization of this event, which will be hosted in its third edition at the University of Florida in 2023.
